en.template: In stressed syllables, the letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɑ/.
In stressed syllables, the letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɑ/.
In stressed syllables, the letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /o/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ always sounds like /o/; ⟨{char}⟩ inherently carries the stress, so it is never unstressed.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ always sounds like /u/, regardless of stress.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ always sounds like /u/, regardless of stress.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ always sounds like /ɨ/, regardless of stress.
In stressed syllables, the letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɛ/.
In stressed syllables, the letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /ɛ/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ usually sounds like /i/; it seldom reduces in sung Russian.
The soft sign makes no sound of its own, but it is phonologically significant: ⟨{char}⟩ palatalizes most consonants that precede it.

The hard sign makes no sound of its own, but it is phonologically significant in two ways: ⟨{char}⟩ preserves the hardness of the preceding consonant, then it triggers a /j/-glide before the next vowel.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /b/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /v/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /ɡ/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /d/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ʒ/; one of the three "hard" consonants in Russian, ⟨{char}⟩ resists palatalization, and only softens in the rarest loanwords or archaic traditional pronunciation.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /z/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /j/; although English speakers call this a semi-vowel, Russian phonologists classify it as a palatalized consonant.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /k/.
In sung Russian, ⟨{char}⟩ is never transcribed alone as simply /l/, but always as either its "hard" allophone [ɫ], or its soft allophone [lʲ].
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /m/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /n/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /p/.
In sung Russian, the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is a lightly trilled /r/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /s/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /t/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /f/.
The default sound for the letter ⟨{char}⟩ is /x/.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ts/; one of the three "hard" consonants in Russian, ⟨{char}⟩ resists palatalization, and only softens in words with the suffix -ция.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /tʃʲ/; one of the three "soft" consonants in Russian, ⟨{char}⟩ is inherently palatalized.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ʃ/; one of the three "hard" consonants in Russian, ⟨{char}⟩ resists palatalization, and only softens in the rarest loanwords.
The letter ⟨{char}⟩ sounds like /ʃʲʃʲ/; one of the three "soft" consonants in Russian, ⟨{char}⟩ is inherently palatalized.
(Grayson, {pages})
